1998

The Dr. Thomas Kiel Arboretum, named after a former Columbia student and co-founder of the Friends of the Morningside Park, is planted.

2016

Harmful algae blooms in the pond.

2017

The waterfall is briefly restored but breaks down next year.

Early 2023

Minju O’Rourke, SEAS ’25, reaches out to Joaquim Goes, suggesting the use of an autonomous boat for his general marine ecosystem research. The boat was eventually used to address the pond’s algae.

June 2023

“Fix the Morningside Park pond and waterfall” petition is created.

We’ve lived in the neighborhood for YEARS and have never been able to see the lovely waterfall!

- Amanda Liew, petition signer

I have never seen the waterfall here. But I have noticed the weathering where it used to be. Very sad. The pond is so polluted, those poor turtles ❤️ They recently had a construction that was dragged out for months. During that time, I believe the water was drained at least a few inches. So scary…save the pond!!!!!!

- Ann Merlow, petition signer

July 2023

University President Minouche Shafik announces a research partnership between Columbia Climate School and the New York City Parks Department to curb the toxic algae at the pond.

Columbia Engineering will repair broken water pumps and fix the waterfall.

January 2024

Columbia engineers discover that the pumps in the pond were burning out, amplifying the algae and waterfall problems. Climate scientists develop a solution for the algae.

Sources: Spectator reporting; “Fix the Morningside Park pond and waterfall” petition; Columbia Neighbors, “Columbia and NYC Parks to Tackle Toxic Summer Algae, Starting at Morningside Park”; Patch, “Locals Push To Restore Harlem Park Waterfall: 'Let's Get It Back'”; Olmsted Network, “Good News for Morningside Park’s Beloved Pond and Waterfall”

Graphic by Jenny Ye
